However I agree that mobs and other entities should get the darker shading as they currently look out of place.

You technically can using a NBT Editor.

The code for Single Biome world is inside of Bedrock Edition, but there is no UI to create one. They can only be accessed by editing a world's code or via a third-party site. This code supports all biomes in Bedrock Edition, including removed biomes and the newest biomes.

In Bedrock Single Biome, there are a few quirks, such as:

  • Mineshafts and strongholds generate in every biome.
  • Single Biome affects the End but not Nether.
  • Nonland biomes do not generate their terrain.
  • Oceans and rivers when inside of a Nether biome have a checkerboard-like pattern of water and lava.
  • Structure generation cuts off at y-level 256 when in a nether or end biome.

This feature is neither widely known nor is it fully developed, and is unlikely to be fully implemented into the game, but it can still be accessed.

Open source is not the correct word when it comes to Java edition. Java bytecode is made to be easily decompileable - that means, you can convert a binary program back into Java source code. In fact Java edition is not open source but with reverse-engineering tools you can reproduce the source code of Java edition very well. This is what mod loaders for Java edition do. This does not make Java edition 'open source', it remains 'closed source' as you don't have the original source code.
Bedrock edition is neither open source, but it is not written in Java and therefore harder to decompile. However, Mojang provides a public API for Bedrock edition, which is actually open source, but this API does not directly expose any of the Bedrock edition code itself, it's just a wrapper around some hidden, closed source code. Hence, there is no parity issue, unless you of course look at the fact that Java edition has no public API :)

When you buy something, you should probably be able to see what you bought.

Technically, we do have NBT tags for commands. Sadly, it's limited to the /give command, mostly for the use of CanPlaceOn and CanDestroy, if not completely. Having said that, I agree. Testing if a player has a specific piece of armor or an item in their inventory is a good reason to have it.

EBREH

I think that both achievements and advancements should exist in both versions of the game!

Because I know they're often considered the same thing, let me clarify: Advancements are on Java edition, and are specific to each world. Achievements are on Bedrock edition, and work in all worlds in which you can earn them. Achievements also unlock character creator items.

So if we have advancements being smaller goals linked to a specific world, and achievements being bigger goals for all your worlds, I think that parity would work.
